So far, Trump himself has not taken to the trail to promote the landmark legislation, though Vice President JD Vance has been visiting key battlegrounds to do so.

The legislation’s cuts to health insurance programs already threaten hundreds of thousands of jobs. This month, a hospital chain in Virginia announced a consolidation it said is in part necessitated by “the One Big Beautiful Bill Act and the resulting realities for healthcare delivery.”

A Republican operative working on Senate races said Trump’s legislative package will give business leaders certainty on taxes over the next few years. But this person was mindful of how the job market looks now, particularly for younger voters struggling to find entry-level jobs.

“Trump realizes that you really need to gas this thing up to get people hiring and get confidence in the market,” this person said. “So it’s not an overnight switch that the president could flip to get people hiring young men into the economy.”

A Washington Post-Ipsos poll conducted this month found that while just 40% of voters approved of Trump’s handling of the economy, Republicans still held a 7-point edge over Democrats on which party voters trust more on the issue.
Pennsylvania’s new Democratic Party Chairman Eugene DePasquale said he wants to get Keystone State Democrats to “focus like a laser” on economic issues.

“But it’s one thing to have people be upset about Trump,” DePasquale said. “It’s another thing for them to vote for us. … We’ve also got to show we’re listening and putting real ideas on the table to try to win him back.”
Moore said Republicans will need “to remind people of how bad things were under Biden” while framing the president’s signature legislation not as a tax cut but as a job creation bill.

“Look, you can’t fool people on the economy,” Moore said. “People know what’s going on. They know what it costs to buy groceries. They know what jobs are available. When Biden was saying, ‘Oh, [inflation is] transitory,’ and so on, it didn’t fool people. So these policies have to be shown to be working.”

title: Kamala Harris calls out fellow Democrats, and Jimmy Kimmel's ratings bonanza
summary: Cal Raleigh joins MLB’s record books, the Trump administration makes an autism claim, and a streamer delays a poignant show’s release.
story: Cal Raleigh joins MLB’s record books, the Trump administration makes an autism claim, and a streamer delays a poignant show’s release. Test your knowledge of this week’s news, and take last week’s quiz here.

title: Hurricane Humberto strengthens to a Category 4 storm
summary: Hurricane Humberto grew to a Category 4 storm Friday and is expected to strengthen further, forecasters said, but it is predicted to stay out to sea and far from the U.S.
story: Hurricane Humberto grew to a Category 4 storm Friday and is expected to strengthen further, forecasters said, but it is predicted to stay out to sea and far from the U.S. East Coast.
The storm, one of two weather systems in the Atlantic, had maximum sustained winds of 145 mph around 11 p.m., the National Hurricane Center said in an update.

There were no coastal watches or warnings late Friday. The forecast track shows a predicted path northwest and then north and northeast, passing between the U.S. East Coast and Bermuda, according to the hurricane center.
A second disturbance is expected to strengthen to a tropical storm and could affect the U.S.
Potential Tropical Cyclone 9 was northwest of the eastern tip of Cuba late Friday and was expected to become a tropical storm over the weekend, the hurricane center said.

"The system is expected to be at or near hurricane intensity when it approaches the southeast U.S. coast early next week, where there is a risk of storm surge and wind impacts," the center said in a forecast discussion late Friday.
A tropical storm warning was in place for the Central Bahamas and a tropical storm watch was in place for parts of the northwest Bahamas, the agency said Friday.
Maximum sustained winds for that storm were 35 mph Friday night, it said. A tropical storm has sustained winds of 39 to 73 mph.
The disturbance could bring up to a foot of rain for eastern Cuba and 4 to 8 inches of rain to the Bahamas.
It is forecast to move north next to Florida's Atlantic coast and toward South Carolina by Monday and Tuesday, according to the hurricane center's map of its possible track.

"There is significantly more uncertainty in the track forecast after day 3, but at the very least it appears that the system will slow down considerably and perhaps even stall near the coast of South Carolina," the agency said in the forecast discussion.

title: 5 questions experts have about Trump's pharma tariffs
summary: For people who rely on certain prescription drugs, including weight loss, asthma and cancer medications, President Donald Trump’s post announcing 100% tariffs on foreign brand-name drugs offers little clarity on when — or if — medications might see price hikes.
story: For people who rely on certain prescription drugs, including weight loss, asthma and cancer medications, President Donald Trump’s post announcing 100% tariffs on foreign brand-name drugs offers little clarity on when — or if — medications might see price hikes.

“Starting October 1st, 2025, we will be imposing a 100% Tariff on any branded or patented Pharmaceutical Product, unless a Company IS BUILDING their Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Plant in America,” Trump said on Truth Social late Thursday. “‘IS BUILDING’ will be defined as, ‘breaking ground’ and/or ‘under construction.’ There will, therefore, be no Tariff on these Pharmaceutical Products if construction has started.”
Experts say Trump’s post raises a lot of questions. Here are five major ones.
What drugs will be impacted?

Trump’s post doesn’t specify whether brand-name drugmakers with an existing U.S. plant would be exempt, whether that exemption would include all their products, or whether it would only be for the drugs manufactured at the U.S. site.

Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly, makers of the weight loss drugs Wegovy and Zepound, respectively, have announced plans to invest in U.S. manufacturing. But it’s unclear if their intent to invest will warrant an exemption.

On Tuesday, Lilly announced plans for a $6.5 billion manufacturing facility in Houston that will produce Zepbound and its other GLP-1 drug, Mounjaro, following a recent commitment to build a $5 billion plant near Richmond, Virginia. Novo Nordisk, a Danish company, said in June it would spend $4.1 billion to construct a second GLP-1 fill-finish plant in Clayton, North Carolina.

AstraZeneca, which makes the asthma drug Symbicort, also announced in July that it will invest $50 billion over the next five years to expand its research and development and manufacturing footprint in the U.S.
Many other popular brand-name drugs, however, are primarily manufactured overseas, particularly in Europe, said Rena Conti, an associate professor at Boston University’s Questrom School of Business.

Botox, made by Allergen, and the cancer drug Keytruda from drugmaker Merck are made in Ireland. (Keytruda’s manufacturing has increasingly moved to the United States in recent years, but it’s not clear if that would earn an exemption from Trump’s tariffs.)
Others, including some for blood and lung cancers, as well as vaccines, are made in places like India and China, Conti said.

“I think what’s most at risk here are branded products that come from China and India,” she said. The E.U. and Japan already have trade agreements in place that cover pharmaceuticals, she added, and it’s unclear whether the new tariff will supersede that.
Will patients see prices increase?
Only 1 in 10 of the prescriptions filled in the U.S. are for brand-name drugs; the vast majority are for generics, which are much cheaper and will not be affected by these tariffs.

Whether patients see price increases will depend on how many drugmakers receive exemptions — and on whether companies choose to pass those costs on to patients at the pharmacy counter, said Dr. Aaron Kesselheim, a professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School. ​​
“Ultimately, tariffs are taxes on patients,” Kesselheim said, “and to the extent that drug companies see increases in cost due to tariffs, they will pass those costs on to patients.”

Some companies may decide not to pass the costs along. So far, the 15% tariffs on imports from the E.U. haven’t translated into big price hikes for U.S. patients, Conti noted. To be sure, a 100% tariff would be far more costly for a company.

Price hikes may not start right away, as drugmakers find out whether they qualify for an exemption. There also might be a lag since U.S. law prevents drugmakers from increasing the price of drugs faster than inflation.
“What if you’re doing updates to the plant you currently have? What if you’re planning a facility? Do those count?” Kesselheim said. “It’s all very ambiguous.”

Some patients may not notice additional price hikes at all, given how costly brand-name drugs already are in the U.S., said Arthur Caplan, the head of the Division of Medical Ethics at NYU Langone Medical Center in New York City.
“I can certainly predict that some patients will immediately feel price increases that will shock them on some of these drugs,” Caplan said.
Could insurers absorb the costs?
Insurers and middlemen, known as pharmacy benefit managers, could try to negotiate drugmakers or absorb some of the tariff-related costs, Caplan said.
It’s more likely, however, that they’d pass it on to patients in the short term, potentially in the form of a larger copay, he said.

It’s not only patients with private insurance that should be worried about price hikes, Kesselheim said. Those who get their drugs covered through government health programs could also see price increases.

“The government is the largest purchaser of prescription drugs in the market, through Medicare, Medicaid and the VA, so it’s really the government or government payers that are going to see the largest impact on price increases,” he said.
Will tariffs spur more U.S. drug manufacturing?
It’s unlikely, Kesselheim said. The decision to build a plant “is a complicated and expensive one” that requires several regulatory hurdles and years of planning.
Conti noted that by the time new manufacturing plants are completed, Trump would likely be out of office.

“It is somewhere between two years and five years to get new production facilities built,” she said, “and it can be in the millions of dollars depending on whether the product that you’re making is a small molecule drug or a biologic.”
Even putting money back into an existing plant isn’t quick.

“If you want to switch a line or retool a factory to make a product, then we’re talking about somewhere between 18 to 36 months to do that,” Conti said, “because you have to show the U.S. regulator that you can make it at this factory at scale, and the product is what it says it is, or is high quality and meets the quality standards of the U.S.”

In a statement, Alex Schriver, a spokesperson for the trade group the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, said “most innovative medicines prescribed in America are already made in America” and companies continue to invest in the U.S.

“Tariffs risk those plans because every dollar spent on tariffs is a dollar that cannot be invested in American manufacturing or the development of future treatments and cures,” Schriver said. “Medicines have historically been exempt from tariffs because they raise costs and could lead to shortages.”
What about shortages?
If Trump keeps his focus solely on brand-name drugs, U.S. patients are unlikely to face shortages, Kesselheim said.
“Their profits are just so, so far beyond this tariff cost that they could probably be OK or raise the prices of the drugs,” he said. “They would probably not stop production as a result.”

But that excludes, he added, some smaller companies who may make niche brand-name products and may not have the resources to take on the extra costs. If tariffs extend to generics, the risk is far greater, Caplan added.

Unlike brand-name drugs, generic drugs are typically sold at close to the cost they’re made, he said, which makes it difficult for companies to justify the cost of building a new facility. They’d likely be forced to walk away from production or close their plants altogether.

title: U.S. rejects international AI oversight at U.N. General Assembly
summary: The United States clashed with world leaders over artificial intelligence at the United Nations General Assembly this week.
story: NEW YORK — The United States clashed with world leaders over artificial intelligence at the United Nations General Assembly this week, rejecting calls for global oversight as many pushed for new collaborative frameworks.

While many heads of state, corporate leaders and prominent figures endorsed a need for urgent international collaboration on AI, the U.S. delegation criticized the role of the U.N. and pushed back on the idea of centralized governance of AI.

Representing the U.S. in Wednesday’s Security Council meeting on AI, Michael Kratsios, the director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, said, “We totally reject all efforts by international bodies to assert centralized control and global governance of AI.”
The path to a flourishing future powered by AI does not lie in “bureaucratic management,” Kratsios said, but instead in “the independence and sovereignty of nations.”

While Kratsios shot down the idea of combined AI governance, President Donald Trump said in his speech to the General Assembly on Tuesday that the White House will be “pioneering an AI verification system that everyone can trust” to enforce the Biological Weapons Convention.

“Hopefully, the U.N. can play a constructive role, and it will also be one of the early projects under AI,” Trump said. AI “could be one of the great things ever, but it also can be dangerous, but it can be put to tremendous use and tremendous good.”.

In a statement to NBC News, a State Department spokesperson said, “The United States supports like-minded nations working together to encourage the development of AI in line with our shared values. The US position in international bodies is to vigorously advocate for international AI governance approaches that promote innovation, reflect American values, and counter authoritarian influence.”
The comments rejecting collaborative efforts around AI governance stood in stark contrast to many of the initiatives being launched at the General Assembly.

On Thursday, the U.N. introduced the Global Dialogue on AI Governance, the U.N.’s first body dedicated to AI governance involving all member states. U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres said the body would “lay the cornerstones of a global AI ecosystem that can keep pace with the fastest-moving technology in human history.” Speaking after Guterres, Nobel Prize recipient Daron Acemoglu outlined the growing stakes of AI’s rapid development, arguing that “AI is the biggest threat that humanity has faced.”

But in an interview with NBC News, Amandeep Singh Gill, the U.N.’s special envoy for digital and emerging technologies, told NBC News that the United States’ critical perception of the U.N.’s role in international AI governance was misconstrued.

“I think it’s a misrepresentation to say that the U.N. is somehow getting into the regulation of AI,” Gill said. “These are not top-down power grabs in terms of regulation. The regulation stays where regulation can be done in sovereign jurisdictions.”
Instead, the U.N.’s mechanisms “will provide platforms for international cooperation on AI governance,” Gill said.

In remarks immediately following Kratsios’ comments, China’s Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Ma Zhaoxu said, “It is vital to jointly foster an open, inclusive, fair and nondiscriminatory environment for technological development and firmly oppose unilateralism and protectionism.”
“We support the U.N. playing a central role in AI governance,” Ma said.

One day after Kratsios’ remarks at the Security Council, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez seemed to push back on Kratsios and gave full-throated support for international cooperation on AI and the U.N.’s role in AI governance.

“We need to coordinate a shared vision of AI at a global level, with the U.N. as the legitimate and inclusive forum to forge consensus around common interests,” Sánchez said. “The time is now, when multilateralism is being most questioned and attacked, that we need to reaffirm how suitable it is in addressing challenges such as those represented by AI.”

Reacting to the week’s developments, Renan Araujo, director of programs for the Washington, D.C.-based Institute for AI Policy and Strategy, told NBC News that “no one wants to see a burdensome, bureaucratic governance structure, and the U.S. has succeeded in starting bilateral and minilateral coalitions. At the same time, we should expect AI-related challenges to become more transnational in nature as AI capabilities become more advanced.”

This is not the first time the U.N. has addressed AI, having passed the Global Digital Compact last year. The compact laid the foundation for the AI dialogue and for an independent international scientific panel to evaluate AI’s abilities, risks and pathways forward. Guterres announced that nominations to this panel are now open.

While Thursday’s event marked the launch of the global dialogue and panel, the dialogue will have its first full meeting in Geneva in summer 2026, in tandem with the International Telecommunication Union’s annual AI for Good summit. The dialogue’s exact functions and first actions will be charted out over the coming months.

title: Robert Irwin Enlists His 'DWTS' Partner Witney Carson to Check His DMs After Saying He's Single
summary: Robert Irwin and his “Dancing With the Stars” partner Witney Carson are “coming in hot” to check his DMs after he revealed his relationship status
story: Robert Irwin and his “Dancing With the Stars” partner Witney Carson are “coming in hot” to check his DMs after he revealed his relationship status.

The 21-year-old wildlife conservationist was recently asked if he’s single and what he’s looking for in a partner. His response caught the attention of many, who have become enamored with his charisma as he competes on the new season of “DWTS.”
In an Instagram video shared on Sept. 26, Irwin and Carson played off the attention by recording themselves entering their rehearsal and having the dancer go through his direct message on his phone.
“Witney taking the wingman job very seriously…” Irwin captioned the clip, with “Coming in hot to check Robert’s DM” written on the video.
Irwin’s older sister and “DWTS” Season 21 winner Bindi Irwin couldn’t help but comment on the post.
“I feel like I finally have the sister I always wanted (and needed)…” Bindi Irwin wrote.

Robert Irwin and Carson are tied for first place following their “DWTS” Week 2 performances on Sept. 23. After the competition,  E! News asked Robert Irwin if he had a romantic partner outside the ballroom. He revealed he was single.
“Yeah, we are still looking for the American girl,” he said, adding that Carson has been “helping.”
Carson joked that people would have to go “through a screening process.”
“Submit your applications through my DMs, then I will forward them to Bindi. And then, then we will see about the American tourist,” she said.

Robert Irwin was also asked what he's looking for in a partner, to which he replied, “I think more than anything else just genuine kindness... That’s so important, to surround yourself with people who are genuinely kind.”
Adding, “My life is a whirlwind, it’s an adventure. I would love to be able to share that with someone and to share those little moments.”
He said that he’s had “a lot of great role models in the love department” and people that he considers “couple goals.”
“So I want to find that,” he said. “It’s something you kind of can’t rush. It just has to happen and you’ve got to be open to that. I know she’s out there and I look forward to it.”

title: Why Does Robert Irwin Sing Along During 'DWTS' Performances? He Explains
summary: Robert Irwin explains why he sings along to the music while performing on "Dancing With the Stars."
story: Robert Irwin has his own method of winning.
During a Sept. 23 interview with Us Weekly, the wildlife conservationist, 21, explained why he likes to sing along to the music when competing on Season 34 of "Dancing with the Stars."
“I (have) no idea about dance, but I do know I love music,” he said.
Irwin — who is the only son of late "Crocodile Hunter" star Steve Irwin and Terri Irwin — added his partner, Witney Carson, keeps telling him to “feel that music” when they’re performing.

“For me, singing it, getting into it, and just giving every fiber of my being to this experience, that’s why I’m here,” he said. “I’m so lucky that I have someone like Witney to direct all of this ridiculous tornado of passion and energy into some semblance of skill.”
Robert Irwin noted that Carson also tells him to “let the music move your body” and “take control.”
Carson’s advice appears to be working. Irwin and the professional dancer came out on top during the premiere episode of “Dancing With the Stars.”

The duo, who performed a jive to “Born To Be Wild” by Steppenwolf, received one of the highest scores of the night. They were given a 15/20 along with “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” star Whitney Leavitt and her partner, Mark Ballas, who also received the same score.
Then, for Week 2, he also did well and got a score of 22/30. That night, fans learned that couple Corey Feldman and Jenna Johnson were eliminated along with Baron Davis and Britt Stewart.

In a May interview with TODAY, Robert Irwin talked about his chances of winning “Dancing with the Stars,” and said he received some "tips" from sister Bindi Irwin, who previously won Season 21 of the dancing competition show.
“She was incredible,” he said of her performances. “So I am really leaning on all of her knowledge. She’s given me a few tips already, but she never danced either.”

title: Corey Feldman Apologizes to 'DWTS' Pro Jenna Johnson for 'Negativity' Around Their Partnership
summary: After his 'DWTS' exit, Corey Feldman thanked Jenna Johnson, addressed rumors of tension, and called their partnership “enjoyable.”
story: Corey Feldman’s time on “Dancing With the Stars” was short-lived, but he gave people plenty to talk about.

The actor formed part of the "DWTS" Season 34 cast, which kicked off earlier this month. Prior to the premiere, Feldman had been making headlines with rumors circulating that he hadn’t been rehearsing with his partner, Jenna Johnson.
Reigning champ Johnson and Feldman were eliminated during the show’s second episode, along with former NBA star Baron Davis and Britt Stewart.
In a Sept. 24 Instagram comment to Johnson, the actor apologized for the “negativity” surrounding their time on the dancing competition show.
Johnson posted a slideshow with photos of them in the ballroom and rehearsal on her Instagram, reflecting on her and Feldman's time together.

“Corey 💘 Our time together was cut short but I am SO grateful for the incredible weeks we did get to share!! Thank you for the giggles everyday in rehearsal, thank you for the hard work, and thank you for sharing your life lessons and memories with me!” she wrote. “I’ll cherish our friendship forever. Never stop dancing 🕺🏻*Everyone go check his new EP he just released!!!!”
Feldman, on his end, replied to Johnson, thanking her and denying any drama between them.

"Thank U Jenna! U were an absolute joy to work with. Im so sorry for any negativity the media is using to give the false narrative that our time together was anything less than enjoyable," he commented. "And U know as well as i do that i was there 7 days a week for the past 3 weeks, doing everything in my power to give U my best, even if the judges couldnt see it. God Bless your family. Keep dancing the dream."

Prior to the new season kicking off, Johnson addressed Feldman’s whereabouts and why they hadn’t been posting TikToks like many of the other couples. In the since-expired Instagram story, the pro said she hadn’t seen Feldman since the cast announcement because he “had some previous work engagements and personal stuff going on.”
They eventually “entered the TikTok” chat on Sept. 9, a week before the Sept. 16 premiere and carried on with their rehearsals.

On the first night of competitions, the couple landed at the bottom of the leaderboard after they danced the tango to “It’s Still Rock & Roll To Me” by Billy Joel. They received a 9 out of 20. For Week 2, they danced a cha-cha to “Baby Got Back” by Sir Mix-A-Lot, scoring a 15 out of 30.
Their combined score of 24 out of 50 placed them in last place. That night was also a double elimination and they took their final bow.
When asked about his experience, Feldman said Johnson had been an “amazing” partner and she “deserved better.”

title: Rick Springfield Ran Into Dick Van Dyke, 99, at the Gym and Was Impressed By His Routine
summary: Rick Springfield was apparently in awe of Dick Van Dyke after bumping into the Hollywood legend at a local gym."Filming an episode of Men’s Health and I went to the gym and who should be there but 99 year-old Dick Van Dyke working out on every machine," the "Jessie's Girl" singer, 76, captioned a photo of the two men on Instagram Sept.
story: Rick Springfield was apparently in awe of Dick Van Dyke after bumping into the Hollywood legend at a local gym.

"Filming an episode of Men’s Health and I went to the gym and who should be there but 99 year-old Dick Van Dyke working out on every machine," the "Jessie's Girl" singer, 76, captioned a photo of the two men on Instagram Sept. 26.

"Dick has lived in Malibu for about 30 years and is an awesome human being," Springfield continued. "I thought I was doing well at 76, but Dick got up from the chest press machine and did a little dance step before I left! Amazing!"
Springfield's gym photo comes a little less than three months after Van Dyke missed co-hosting a comedy event with his wife, Arlene Silver, because of an illness, People reported at the time.
Van Dyke, who celebrates his 100th birthday on Dec. 13, shared a video shortly after his 99th birthday last year to demonstrate how he stays in such amazing shape.
In the clip, the "Mary Poppins" star was seen effortlessly doing leg presses at the gym.
The same month, Van Dyke also danced in a Coldplay video for the band's song “All My Love."

The special extended director’s cut video was shot at the Malibu home Van Dyke shares with Silver. It shows the actor singing along with Coldplay lead singer Chris Martin and dancing with family members as he talks about a few highlights in his life.
The video also captures Van Dyke opening up about the mindset he uses to approach each new day.

“I am acutely aware that I can go any day now,” he says in the video. “But I don’t know why it doesn’t concern me. I’m not afraid of it. I have that feeling totally against anything intellectual I have, that I am going to be all right.”
Van Dyke added that he considers himself “one of those lucky people who got to do for a living what I would have done anyway.”
“When you think how lucky I am," the actor says, "I got to do what I do: play and act silly."

title: Meghan Markle Shares Rare Look of Her California Home — And Her Sleepy Pup
summary: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, may be showing off her new As Ever vase but all eyes are on her home decor.
story: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, may be showing off her new As Ever vase but all eyes are on her home decor.
The former Meghan Markle gave her followers a rare look inside her and Prince Harry's Montecito, California, home in a Sept. 26 Instagram story.

The clip begins with a look at a sleepy Mia, one of the family's dogs, lying on top of a cream-colored boucle chair and footrest with a beige fuzzy blanket. Behind the pup is a beige-and-cream throw blanket. In the distance is an open glass door with a wooden frame that appears to lead to an outdoor area, complete with chairs and a side table, overlooking a green garden.
As Meghan continues to film, she pans over to a gorgeous bouquet on top of a black pedestal side table. She zooms in on the white vase that features the logo of her lifestyle brand, As Ever.
“Delphinium, Nigella, Veronica — meet As Ever. With garden roses and Queen Anne’s Lace,” Meghan wrote, adding in parenthesis, “And a very sleepy Mia.”
She also wrote, “Looking lovely ladies,” along with a floral bouquet emoji.
Aside from the eye-pleasing snippet of her cozy room, fans can admire the dark wooden floors, beige curtains and large grey stone floor vase.
Meghan has shared glimpses of her home here and there on social media, as well as in some interviews over the years.

Many people thought they were immersed inside her kitchen and outdoor area during her Netflix show “With Love, Meghan.” However, it was later revealed that the mother of two doesn't film at her actual home, instead at a nearby rental.

“I wanted to protect that safe haven,” she told People earlier this year. “We’re a close-knit family, and I love those moments — putting Lili down for a nap, having lunch together, having sacred time together at the end of the day. Our kitchen is where Mama just cooks for the family, and with a crew of 80-plus people, that’s a lot of people to have in your house!”
She did note that some of the scenes filmed in the family’s chicken coop, garden and orchard are on their property.

As for her lifestyle brand, Meghan first unveiled the project in March 2024. It was originally known as American Riviera Orchard, before she announced the new name on her Instagram account on Feb. 18.
Currently, the brand's shop includes her strawberry jam, teas, crepes mix and more. And by the looks of her Instagram story, looks like fans will have to be on the lookout for the chic vase.

title: Why Jesse Williams Chose 'Hotel Costiera' as His 1st Show Post 'Grey's Anatomy: EXCLUSIVE
summary: Jesse Williams is stepping out of the “Grey’s” and into the light with his new Prime Video series, “Hotel Costiera”
story: Jesse Williams is stepping out of the “Grey’s” and into the light with his new Prime Video series, “Hotel Costiera.”

Filmed at a real-life luxury hotel on Italy’s Amalfi Coast, Williams throws away his bedside manner to embody Daniel De Luca, a U.S. Marine intelligence officer who now works to solve crimes as fixer for the hotel’s owner, Augusto (Tommaso Ragno), and his daughter Adele (Maria Chiara Giannetta).
In an interview with TODAY.com, Williams, 44, admits it was refreshing to take a step back from “serious subjects” and jump into something more “comedic” and “light.”
“That’s a big part of the appeal. It was a place to play, be light, fun, funny, creative … amidst all the chaos in the world,” he says.

“A lot of my life is around serious subjects. So it was nice to be able to have my work be a little bit different, something where we can kind of take an old school format and do some action. I like to be physical and do something comedic, as well as something with a little bit of stakes.”

Taking big swings is not something new to Williams. The actor made a lasting impression during his Broadway debut in the 2022 revival of the play “Take Me Out.” The production, which also starred Jesse Tyler Ferguson, Patrick J. Adams and Michael Oberholtzer, among others, won a Tony Award for best revival of a play that year, and gave Ferguson his first Tony for best featured actor in a play.

That same year, Williams also took a turn on another murder mystery series when he was cast as a guest star on Season 3 of “Only Murders in the Building” and played Tobert, a cameraman and documentary filmmaker.
But his time around, Williams, who fans came to know and love as Dr. Jackson Avery on "Grey’s Anatomy" for 12 seasons, says he was focused on doing something across the pond.

“I was really interested in storytelling outside of the country, like traveling somewhere and putting together a cast from other countries and having this kind of cultural melange to play with. I thought that it was a good time for this,” he tells TODAY.com.
To accomplish this feat, Williams enlisted a dialect coach to help him learn the romance language.

“I had somebody on Zoom, before I left the country, and then there was somebody on set, just helping me,” he says of his processes to speak the language in occasional scenes. “I kind of had to learn the fundamentals of the language, learn the language, syntax construction, and then my lines, which are always changing, and have to be malleable.”

But don’t expect the actor to be fluent in the millennium-old tongue. “I’m no good with languages,” Williams says laughing, adding “Some people can just adjust and pick it up pretty quickly. I would not say that’s a strong suit for me ... it was work.”

Over the course of six episodes, viewers will see Williams solve different cases as he simultaneously looks into the disappearance of the hotel owner’s younger daughter, Alice (Amanda Campana). Though her family doubts something’s amiss, Daniel believes that she’s in trouble.
While Williams’ character appears to have no issues solving mysteries and being the disarming sleuth, the “Grey’s Anatomy” alum says he doesn’t have much in common with the Marine-turned-fixer.

“I think he’s so institutionally trained, it’s very opposite of me,” he tells TODAY.com. “I couldn’t imagine putting myself through the things that he’s put himself through in terms of working his way up the ranks of the military and the culture there. So that’s where we differ. I think a willingness to find the humor in things is, probably, a place that we overlap.”
As for solving crimes? Williams says he’s “observant” — but it's going to be a stretch if you expect him to solve an actual murder.
“I think I do pick up on body language and certainly attention to detail,” he says thoughtfully, before emphasizing that he’d only make a “decent detective.”

Shorter than the traditional 10 or 12 episode series, “Hotel Costiera” is an sufficient tease for fans who love murder mysteries and crime dramas, but it will undoubtedly leave them wanting for more. Williams says there’s an easy fix for that. He tells TODAY.com that while the limited series closes the loop in the final episode, the show is “poised for a whole lot of story.”

“There’s a lot of mysterious, interesting material in that coastline, in the history of a country that’s thousands of years old and still has the structures to prove it,” he says. “There’s a lot we could be doing there.”
“So binge away and we’ll have a chance to keep telling you stories,” he quips.
“Hotel Costiera,” also starring Jordan Alexandra and Antonio Gerardi, is now available to stream on Prime Video.

title: James Van Der Beek Says Eldest Child Left Him in 'Awe' in 'Dawson's Creek' Reunion
summary: James Van Der Beek gushed about oldest child Olivia taking part in the "Dawson's Creek" reunion shortly before her 15th birthday.
story: James Van Der Beek is one proud papa.
The “Dawson’s Creek” alum was beaming with pride after his eldest child appeared at a reading of the show’s pilot earlier this week in New York City shortly before her birthday.

Van Der Beek was replaced by Lin-Manuel Miranda after he had to miss the event due to stomach viruses. His wife, Kimberly, and kids turned out, however, with his oldest child, Olivia, helping to sing the show’s popular theme, Paula Cole’s “I Don’t Want to Wait,” onstage surrounded by several of the drama’s stars. Van Der Beek was moved, emotions magnified as she celebrated her birthday just a few days later.

“My oldest turned 15 today,” he wrote Sept. 25 alongside video of the moment on Instagram. “Same age that Dawson was in the pilot. To watch you stand there in that red dress, so confidently taking center stage amidst all those people I’ve known so long and cherish so deeply… I’m just left in awe.”
Van Der Beek, who announced last November that he had been diagnosed with colorectal cancer, applauded how she has grown.

“I’ve always joked that you came out ‘parent proof,’ but this last year, as I’ve watched you accelerate into so many big decisions, jump into so many activities, budget your time, do your homework and your hair (which, from my point of view, seem to require roughly the same amount of time & focus 😂)… the less I think the parent-proof thing is a joke,” he wrote.
Van Der Beek, who has six kids with his wife, then recalled how Olivia handled matters when she once “screwed up” getting his ticket for her high school football game.

“You did something remarkable. Something I’d like to THINK you learned from me (but recognize that might be wishful thinking): You immediately took responsibility. Told me it was your first time doing all of it. Apologized succinctly, then did what you could to fix it,” he wrote. “I was more proud of how you handled the mess-up than if you’d done it all perfectly the start.”
Van Der Beek, 48, then encouraged her to aim high in life.

“Keep taking big swings, kiddo. Risk imperfection,” he wrote. “Keep dreaming big and most importantly, be true to who you are. Because, while only YOU will know exactly who your most authentic self will be, as someone who’s known you your whole life… I can guarantee you’re going to love her. Happy birthday kiddo. I love you.”
While Van Der Beek couldn’t make it to the “Dawson’s Creek” reading, he did make his presence felt with a prerecorded video.

“I have been looking forward to this night for months and months ever since my angel Michelle Williams said she was putting it together,” he said, according to People. “I can’t believe I’m not there. I can’t believe I don’t get to see my castmates, my beautiful cast in person.

“And just I want to stand on that stage and thank every single person in the theater for being here tonight,” he continued. “From the cast to the crew to everybody who’s doing anything and has been so generous, and especially every single last one of you — you are the best fans in the world.”

title: 'Air Bud Returns' Announces 2 Dogs Have Been Cast as Buddy: Meet Summer and Charlie
summary: "Air Bud Returns" director shared that they've casted two dogs to be the next golden retriever named Buddy in the upcoming film. What to know about Charlie and Summer.
story: "Air Bud Returns" has found its Buddy.
After combing through more than 5,000 dogs, Robert Vince, writer and director of “Air Bud Returns," shared that two dogs have been cast for the role of the beloved basketball-playing canine.

"The search for the next Air Bud have been incredible. We couldn't just choose one," he said in a video shared on Air Bud TV's YouTube channel on Sept. 25. "The two winners, they are Summer from San Diego and Charlie from Ohio."
The video then showed clips of Summer and Charlie playing with a ball outside.

"Criteria that we used were, one, did the dog look like the original Air Bud — the stage presence, the personality of Buddy? And two, did it have some training? Did it have a base, a foundation that we could start from? And then finally, the ability to play basketball," he said.
The news was also posted on Air Bud's official Instagram page.

"They’ve got the look. They’ve got the moves. And they’ve got that spark that made Buddy a legend," an IG post read of Summer and Charlie. "Filming kicks off next week in Vancouver. We’re bringing Buddy back for a whole new generation — and you’ve got front row seats to the journey."
Online, fans said they couldn't wait to see the film.
"So excited for this!" one person wrote.
Another said, "Yay! Congrats Charlie & Summer!"

Summer and Charlie will now undergo "training with professional animal trainers before making their big-screen debut in 'Air Bud Returns,'" per the official website of the movie. It also says filming will begin Oct. 1 in Vancouver, Canada.
The movie is expected to hit theaters in summer 2026, according to a press release shared in July.

"Air Bud Returns" is about a 12-year-old boy named Jacob who dreams of being a basketball player, per the release. But everything changes when he sees an original VHS of “Air Bud” in his late father's childhood home and meets a stray golden retriever named Buddy.

"Together they embark on a journey of healing, unite a team of misfits, and chase a championship," reads the release. "Through it all they learn to play from the heart, believe in each other, and always take the shot!"

title: Chris Meloni Reveals He Ad-Libbed *That* Stabler Line in the 'SVU' Premiere: 'Ur Welcome'
summary: Christopher Meloni posted on X he ad-libbed Elliot Stabler saying "love you" to Olivia Benson on the Season 27 "Law & Order: SVU" premiere after Cragen died.
story: No one knows Elliot Stabler and Olivia Benson better than the actors who play them. Just ask them.
Chris Meloni posted on X that he ad-libbed the line that sent Benson and Stabler fans spiraling after the "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" Season 27 premiere Sept. 25.
In the episode, Meloni's character reunites with longtime partner Benson (Mariska Hargitay) after the death of their former captain, Donald Cragen (Dann Florek).
After commiserating over disliking funerals and losing friends, the beloved duo ponder on their past multiyear partnership under Cragen.
“Not that you can go back and not that I’d want to, but — we had a pretty good run there for a minute,” Stabler says.
“We still do,” Benson answers. “Just different.”
Benson embraces Stabler before he opens her car door and says two words that viewers almost never hear them say to each other.
“Love you,” Stabler says to her. “Night.”
The next day, Meloni responded to a fan on X who wrote, "@Chris_Meloni sooooo stabler told benson love you last night care to comment ??"
"Ad lib. Made the cut. Ur welcome," he responded.
What Chris Meloni and Mariska Hargitay Have Said About Stabler and Benson
Meloni, and Hargitay, aren't strangers to crafting dialogue for their characters.
In 2022, he told TODAY.com that tender moments between Benson and Stabler, like a handhold, are "our thing."

“There’s nobody who knows these characters better than she and I. With all due respect to the writers, whatever you see is really she and I figuring it out — figuring out what the exact words are or the exact emotions are,” he said.
Hargitay echoed Meloni's sentiment in an interview with TODAY.com last year.
“Listen, nobody really understands our relationship the way we do,” Hargitay said, “because we have such an incredible shorthand.”
“I trust his choices because he’s incapable of not telling the truth — as a person and an actor,” she added.
Hargitay has also trusted her friend's choices as a writer. She guest-starred in a Season 5 episode of "Law & Order: Organized Crime" that he wrote.
“It was, you know, daring. It was risk-taking. It was moving. It was out of the box, the way he thinks,” she said to TODAY.com of Meloni's “amazing” writing. “It was so fresh and so intimate.”
In April, Meloni told TODAY.com that he “inevitably” rewrites scenes for their characters.
The episode he wrote focused on the dreams Stabler had in a coma and also featured some funny and sweet moments between Stabler and Benson after Stabler woke up.

“I thought it was a natural and correct evolution to get to gain greater insight into their engagements — maybe not where they’re going and all that stuff,” he said. “Those are bigger-ticket items. How they speak to each other, how they feel about each other.”
Where Benson and Stabler are going romantically remains to be seen.
They almost kissed in Benson's kitchen on a 2023 episode of "SVU."
Hargitay said in a May 2024 interview that the scene did not air according to her and Meloni's plan.

“To be honest with you, Chris and I thought it should go one way and the powers that be didn’t, so it got changed at the last minute, that near kiss,” she said. “Obviously, Dick (Wolf, the show’s creator) gets final say. It’s his show and he didn’t want that.”

Meloni addressed “the kitchen thing” in an April 2025 panel with fans, saying, “We were attempting something. I don’t think it worked. But I’m not going to tell you why it didn’t work, because you all have your opinion; I know what transpired.”
Wolf himself recently weighed in on the topic of Benson and Stabler potentially getting together one day during an interview with the Los Angeles Times.
He said fans have been "clamoring for 25 years" for a hookup between the two characters.

“Look, I never say never. But I do learn some lessons from history. When did 'Moonlighting' became unwatchable?” he said, referencing the idea that "Moonlighting" declined in popularity after the two main characters, David Addison (Bruce Willis) and Maddie Hayes (Cybill Shepherd), got together.
"Once they did it, it was over," Wolf said.

title: Would Former 'ER' Star Maura Tierney Appear on 'The Pitt'? What She Told TODAY
summary: Maura Tierney tells the TODAY show whether she'd appear alongside former "ER" co-star Noah Wyle on his HBO Max hit "The Pitt."
story: Could Maura Tierney team up with Noah Wyle for a mini-"ER" reunion on an upcoming season of "The Pitt"?
She would certainly be up for it.

The "Law & Order" star was asked by Al Roker on the 3rd Hour of TODAY on Sept. 26 if she would be interested in appearing on "The Pitt," the Emmy-winning hospital drama that features her former "ER" co-star.
"Sure, I love all those — I worked with everyone over there," Tierney said while sitting alongside "Law & Order" co-star Reid Scott.
The question was prompted by Tierney reuniting with former "ER" co-stars Eriq La Salle and Mekhi Phifer during last season of "Law & Order," which is celebrating its 25th season this fall.

Season 2 of “The Pitt” will be released by HBO Max in January 2026. In addition to Wyle, the show is also co-executive produced by John Wells, the former showrunner and head writer of "ER," and was created by R. Scott Gemmill, a former writer and producer on "ER."
Tierney reminisced about playing Dr. Abby Lockhart on "ER" from 1999 to 2009. She joined the cast five years into the iconic hospital drama's run on NBC.
"We had a blast," she said. "I was sort of in the middle between the OG 'ER' people and then the sort of later iteration of it. It was sort of two parts of it for me, and they both were great."
While it remains to be seen if she puts on her scrubs again for an appearance on "The Pitt" one day, she is enjoying playing Lt. Jessica Brady on "Law & Order."
"It's super fun. I love the cop stuff," she said. "I love the badge work, flashing the badge."

title: 7 Books to Read After 'Buckeye,' According to Author Patrick Ryan
summary: Here are 7 books to read after Buckeye by Patrick Ryan, according to the author.
story: Read With Jenna's September 2025 pick, "Buckeye" by Patrick Ryan, is a long and sweeping epic, covering decades in American history and how it coincides with two families.

When you're done, you might be left craving either more about American history, world wars or a family epic. Luckily, author Ryan recommended seven books that inspired "Buckeye" and may be followups to the book.
Below, find out what Ryan had to say about the books, which range from fiction to nonfiction.
Ordinary People: A Novel

"You might have seen the film adaptation, which is one of my favorite films ever. Still, even if you’re very familiar with the story it tells, if you haven’t read this novel, I can’t recommend it highly enough. A short and very intimate investigation into a family in the wake on one tragedy and headed toward another, told in the present tense. The interiority of the characters is utterly convincing, and what the novel says about forgiveness is gut-wrenching. It’s a gem of a novel."
The Last Of The Doughboys: The Forgotten Generation and Their Forgotten World War

"This is a fascinating and compulsively readable account of Richard Rubin’s project to interview every living First World War veteran — written by Rubin himself. What these nonagenarians and centenarians have to say, and the way they say it (drawing from memories that are still very close to them) will hold you on the edge of your seat and occasionally move you to tears."
Soldier From The War Returning: The Greatest Generation's Troubled Homecoming

“Childers writes the true, intimate and sometimes astonishing lives of three men who come home from the Second World War and find themselves struggling to re-assimilate. It’s not just their stories, though; it’s also the stories of their families and a myth-shattering portrait of a country ill-equipped to accommodate what we now call PTSD."
Nicholas Nickleby (Penguin Classics)

"Whenever I ask someone if they’ve read this book, the answer is almost always no. Even people who loved 'David Copperfield' and Oliver Twist. I know there’s only time for so many Dickens novels in your life — I think I’ve read less than half of them—but if you’re up for a wonderful, long, entertaining, emotional family drama with plenty of characters and lots of twists and turns, I recommend this one."
Plainsong
Eventide

"Two seemingly quiet novels set in the small fictional town of Holt, Colorado. In a no-nonsense voice but lyrical voice, these books dive deep into the hearts and psychologies of characters you’ll fall in love with and care about — including two elderly brothers who are hats-off unforgettable.“
Tell Me Everything: Oprah's Book Club: A Novel

"No one nails character as exactly as Elizabeth Strout, and this is the novel where she takes all the characters she’s been writing about for years and brings them into one narrative. Time is the wind in the sail of this beautiful book, and no one — not even Olive Kitteridge — can stop it."
Dear America: Letters Home from Vietnam

"A heartbreaking and fascinating collection of more than 200 letters written by American soldiers in Vietnam. Each letter is followed by a short update on what happened to the writer —including where the men who came home are now, and what they’re doing. It’s a devastating and necessary book. Collectively, it makes a defining voice from that war that the country couldn’t hear while it was happening."

title: Jessica Sanchez Competed on 'AGT' at 10. A Decade Later, She Won — 9 Months Pregnant
summary: Jessica Sanchez is the winner of America's got Talent. She won at 9 months pregnant. Here's what it's like.
story: Jessica Sanchez has dreamed of winning "America's Got Talent" since she was a little kid. What she had not anticipated was that she would be nine months pregnant when she won.
Sanchez made her "America's Got Talent" in 2005 when she was 10 years old. She sang her way through the show's first season before being voted off in the semifinal round.
This time around, she made it to the show's finale. (In between "AGT" stints, she also came in second place on "American Idol" in 2012).
"When Terry (Crews) was about to announce the winner, I was just standing there thinking about my moments on Season 1, when I was 10 years old, and how badly I wanted this," Sanchez tells TODAY.com.
“I was just thinking how proud my little self would have been making it this far and not ever giving up on my dreams.”
Now 29, Sanchez returned to the show with the same dreams and a life update: She is pregnant with a little girl, whom she plans to name Eliana.
Sanchez first discovered she was pregnant a few days before deciding to audition for "AGT" again.
Even though she knew it would be a difficult, she decided to not let pregnancy stop her from pursuing her dreams.
“This journey has been one of the hardest things I’ve ever had to do, vocally, physically, mentally, and emotionally, because my body is changing and I just keep getting bigger,” Sanchez says.

Sanchez performed a heartfelt rendition of Benson Boone's "Beautiful Things" in her audition. After captivating the crowd with her voice, Sofia Vergara hit the Golden Buzzer, advancing Sanchez directly to the live shows, bypassing the rest of the audition process.
"I didn't expect to get the Golden Buzzer. I honestly had no expectation," Sanchez said. "Sofia (Vergara) saw something special in me, and that really meant the world."

Throughout the season, Sanchez continued to amaze the judges and crowds with her voice. She sang "Ordinary" by Alex Warren earlier in the season and performed "Die With a Smile" by Lady Gage and Bruno Mars in the finale.
Sanchez said that the baby would "kick hard" every time she sang "Golden Hour" by JVKE.
"That song 'Golden Hour' was really special to me, because she was kind of like helping me, or just there really with me during that song," she says.
Now that she is nearing the end of her pregnancy, Sanchez says she is excited to begin a new chapter.

"I'm excited to pour out everything that I've gone through with this experience and just throughout the year fully out into my music and just share it with the world," she says. "Hopefully with each and every platform that I'm given, I inspire people who are also struggling with following their dreams. I just hope to inspire people."

“It's been a long, a long journey, but I'm so grateful for every single minute of it — just getting a chance to sing in front of America again and see what they think of me and my creativity. I cannot believe that I am the winner of Season 20.”

title: Emmys Host Nate Bargatze Reacts to Backlash Over Boys & Girls Club Donation Bit
summary: Nate Bargatze speaks out after the internet was divided over his Boys & Girls Club donation bit at the 2025 Emmys.
story: Nate Bargatze is reflecting on his Emmys hosting duties and the donation bit that divided the internet.
During his Sept. 23 “Nateland” podcast episode, the comedian said that the Boys & Girls Club of America donation was “fun” but knows that some people didn’t like the execution.

In an attempt to keep acceptance speeches short during the Sept. 14 Emmy Awards, Bargatze said he would be donating $100,000 to the organization. However, every time a speech went over the allotted 45-seconds, money would be deducted. If they kept it short, money would be added.
While it seemed good in theory, the show ended with the number in the red because the final speeches took up a lot of time.
“A lot of reviews did not like the Boys & Girls Club thing,” Bargatze told his pals Brian Bates, Aaron Weber and Dusty Slay during the podcast, adding that the idea “came from a real place of heart.”
“Everybody at home loved it,” he continued. “It was fun, it was entertaining seeing money go down and all this.”
He said, he “wasn’t trying to put anyone on the spot” or “trying to make someone donate money.”
“But in my head I kinda thought, ‘Make it fun,’” he continued, noting that the children’s presence or the donation wasn’t “a tool,” he was just trying to find a way to make speeches shorter.

“Honestly, what I thought would happen in the room, I thought it was going to be Netflix donating or Apple. The shows that won,” he said, not expecting 15-year-old “Adolescence” star and winner Owen Cooper covering what had been deducted for his speech going over.

“In my head, I pictured it as they could then go long, but then be a hero,” he said. “So it was like a win-win. Then the night becomes about love and you’re giving to these kids that are there and all this kind of stuff. I don’t know if I just didn’t explain it enough in the room.”
At the end of the night, CBS donated $100,000 and Bargatze put in his own $250,000, making the grand total $350,000.
“I wasn’t gonna give that money at the end,” he said. “I wasn’t thinking I was gonna have to. But the way it went, I was like, ‘Well, I can’t. I’m not gonna not.’”
He said that this donation moment has been his biggest controversy, joking, “It is pretty funny my only controversial thing is the Boys and Girls Club got $350,000.”
Overall, Bargatze said he doesn't regret doing the bit, but would have just better explained the situation. He said he wanted it to be a “giving night” and thanked his fans and friends for tuning in.
He said that he knew he was the “outsider,” but that “the biggest thing that showed was that the ratings went up.”
According to Variety, the 2025 Emmys had 7.4 million viewers, an 8% increase from last year's 6.9 million viewers. The magazine reported that it was the most-watched Emmys since 2021.

title: The 2 Words Elliot Stabler Said to Olivia Benson on ‘SVU’ Have Us Questioning Their Relationship – Again
summary: It’s a “Law & Order” tale as old as time — what is going on with Olivia Benson and Elliot Stabler?
story: It’s a “Law & Order” tale as old as time — what is going on with Olivia Benson and Elliot Stabler?

The Season 27 premiere of “Law & Order: SVU” featured a scene with Mariska Hargitay and Chris Meloni’s characters that is seemingly open to interpretation when it comes to their current relationship status.
Meloni made a guest appearance at the beginning of the episode in honor of Benson and Stabler’s former captain, Donald Cragen (Dann Florek), who viewers learn in the opening moments has died.
After visiting with mourners inside a bar, Benson walks to her car and sees Stabler leaning against it.
“I don’t like funerals,” he says to her.
Benson agrees and says they’re entering their “all our friends are dying era.”

Stabler references their 12-plus years as partners under Cragen, who put up with a lot of their personal and professional antics as two of his detectives, saying, “Not that you can go back and not that I’d want to, but — we had a pretty good run there for a minute.”
“We still do,” Benson answers. “Just different.”
Then they hug beside Benson’s car. (This marks just their fifth hug in 27 seasons, but who’s counting?)
“Now, get off my car,” Benson jokes before she pulls away from Stabler.
Stabler Tells Benson He Loves Her in the ‘Law & Order: SVU’ Season 27 Premiere
He opens the car door for her, but before he closes it, he looks at her and says something that will send Benson and Stabler fans into a frenzy.
“Love you,” Stabler tells her. “Night.”
Many fans have been hoping for years that the two work partners would become romantic partners.

Taking things past friendship was never really an option for Benson and Stabler when they worked under Cragen, as they were paired up at work and Stabler had a wife at home. Despite Stabler separating from, and nearly divorcing, his wife, nothing romantic ever happened between him and Benson back then.

Cragen was the one who broke the news to Benson in the show’s 13th season that Stabler resigned and wasn’t coming back. Ten years later, Stabler returned to Benson’s life, and his wife died. Since then, the two have shared a few close moments, including a near-kiss in Benson’s kitchen.

Now, “love you” is not something these two casually say to each other. In fact, the only other time Stabler said “I love you” to Benson was during a PTSD spiral on “Law & Order: Organized Crime” after his wife died from injuries sustained in a car bombing.

At the time, his children and Benson staged an intervention for Stabler amid his erratic behavior following Kathy’s death. Stabler pushed away their concerns, and Benson asked, “Elliot, tell us what you need.”
“I love you,” he said, while staring at Benson as his kids watched.
Benson looked shocked as his kids just stared. After a few seconds, he added, “I love all of you.”

In a later season of “Organized Crime,” Stabler drunkenly confessed to an old friend that there is a woman he is in love with. While he never shared her name, Benson really was the only person he could’ve been talking about, since he hasn’t seriously dated anyone since Kathy died. She also hasn’t dated anyone since Stabler returned to her life.

The closest Benson came to opening up about her feelings for Stabler was during a chat in Season 24 with friend Amanda Rollins (Kelli Giddish) after they relaxed with wine for some girl talk during a case.
Benson told Rollins she felt like Stabler was her “home,” but she couldn’t move past how he left her and that he was always somebody else’s husband.
“With her gone it’s like there’s nothing but possibility, which is paralyzing,” she said.

Benson’s response in this week’s episode after Stabler says “love you” is quite different from her reaction in that intervention scene. This time around, she seems calm, as if he says it to her on a regular basis.
Hargitay shared a message in a recent interview for fans of a Benson-Stabler romance: “You can never give up hope.”
“I think when people see two humans devoted and loyal and having each other’s back, it’s all any of us want — is that person that always has your back,” she said.

title: Beloved ‘Law & Order: SVU’ Character Dies in Season 27 Premiere
summary: The Season 27 premiere of "Law & Order: SVU" reveals that Capt. Don Cragen (Dann Florek) has died. Chris Meloni also guest stars to honor the OG captain.
story: The 27th season premiere of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” started on a somber note: with a loss of one of their own.
The episode, which aired Thursday night, revealed that the unit’s beloved former captain, Donald Cragen (Dann Florek), has died.

The current captain of the team, Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay), who started out over 25 years ago with the squad under Cragen, walks into a bar filled with current and former colleagues gathered to remember their former leader.

She’s greeted first by George Huang (BD Wong), a psychiatrist who previously assisted the group during the early years, and then embraced by Brian Cassidy (Dean Winters), who was a detective alongside Benson during the show’s first season in 1999. It was also a romantic reunion of sorts since Benson and Cassidy casually hooked up in some of the show’s first episodes, and in later seasons, they reconnected and had a more serious relationship.
Old video of Cragen giving a speech plays on a screen in the bar as Benson watches with her colleagues, including ADA Dominick Carisi (Peter Scanavino).
“I lived for my job. I don’t think that surprises anybody,” he says in the footage, which appears to be from his retirement party. “And I can’t imagine my life any other way.”
Benson tells Carisi that Cragen was “the best boss” she ever had.
“Everything I know about being a captain, I learned from him,” she says.

Cragen oversaw the unit until the show’s 15th season, when he announced his retirement. For most of those years, he dealt with antics involving Detectives Benson, John Munch (Richard Belzer, who died in 2023), Odafin “Fin” Tutuola (Ice-T) and Elliot Stabler (Chris Meloni), who is waiting outside for Benson when she leaves the bar.
Benson and Stabler reminisce on the “pretty good run” they had in the olden days before realizing they’re entering their “all our friends are dying era.”
In real life, Florek appears to be OK. In fact, he was on the set with Hargitay and Meloni while they filmed that Benson and Stabler scene.
Meloni shared a sweet photo of the trio from that night in August.
“Hangin with friends on a Friday nite,” he captioned his Instagram post, tagging Hargitay and Florek.
Capt. Donald Cragen’s 1st and Last ‘Law & Order’ Appearances

Florek’s last on-camera appearance in the “Law & Order” universe was on Meloni’s spinoff, “Organized Crime,” in March 2024, when Cragen faked having a heart attack as a distraction after a group of men stormed the diner where he was meeting Stabler.
He last appeared on “SVU,” virtually, in the show’s 500th episode in 2021.
His character originated in 1990 on the mothership “Law & Order,” where he appeared throughout the early ‘90s before starring full time on “SVU.”
Cragen was a pivotal force in Benson’s life, acting as a father figure to her. He broke the news to her in Season 13 when her longtime partner, Stabler, left, and he championed her career ascent.
“I had this really great boss who believed in me and who told me that I was worthy,” Benson tells a victim during the Sept. 25 episode. “Then eventually, I started to believe it.”

She also recognizes how much she had in common with Cragen, saying, “He worked a lot longer than he needed to because he was so good at his job, because it gave his life meaning. He and I were a lot alike, and I don’t think I fully realized it until after he was gone.”
The paternal role of Cragen also mirrors how Florek sees himself off screen.

“I think Cragen was a father figure to a lot of the people in the show, but for some wonderful reason, I think Dann Florek was kind of a father figure to a lot of the people and the actors,” Florek told TODAY.com in January 2024 on the red carpet in honor of the 25th season of “SVU.”
“I always made a point to go out of my way and welcome everyone when they came in, because I remember when people did it for me,” he said.

title: 'Law & Order' Stars Tony Goldwyn, Hugh Dancy and Odelya Halevi React to Premiere's Surprising Events
summary: "Law & Order" stars Tony Goldwyn, Hugh Dancy and Odelya Halevi speak in an interview with TODAY.com about the Season 25 premiere episode and the ending.
story: The new season of “Law & Order” picked up where last season’s shocking ending left off — with trouble for Maroun (Odelya Halevi).

Season 24 concluded in May with the murder of a man named Carter Mills, who was acquitted in the death of a model. Mills’ DNA on the victim also happened to match evidence from an unsolved 12-year-old case: the murder of ADA Samantha Maroun’s sister, Christina.
After Mills was shot and killed following the acquittal, which came after EADA Nolan Price (Hugh Dancy) didn’t look the other way on a key piece of evidence, the police turned its focus to Maroun.
Halevi tells TODAY.com she “loved” being a person of interest.

“I think at the end of the day, I love playing — finally playing or showing — a side of Maroun that is maybe a bit more dark and not all out there,” she says, “because I think that she’s very opinionated and very emotional. And it’s all out there. She doesn’t hide it.
“And it’s the first time that we are seeing her really dark, really on the gray human side.”
“And concealing things, potentially,” Dancy chimes in.

Dancy and Halevi’s characters butted heads over the case in last season’s finale, and Price questioned Maroun’s innocence. That mistrust is a theme that continues in the Season 25 premiere on Sept. 25.

In last season's finale, their boss, District Attorney Nicholas Baxter (Tony Goldwyn), even used a personal story as an example during a conversation with Price about looking the other way on a piece of evidence in a case that may have cleared the suspect — trying to teach Price, a stickler for following the rules of law, that sometimes it’s OK to be human in the job.
Price later tells Baxter he researched the personal story and couldn’t find any evidence it ever happened (more on this later).
“I had urged, as gently as I can, Nolan to not be so narrow in his view, to think with empathy,” Goldwyn says about his character. “And we’re really seeing the consequences of his not doing that.”

Those consequences are a result of Price sticking to the law. That piece of evidence he turned over was also a personal betrayal to Maroun, as he had to report she tampered with the witness identification process in the case against Mills.
“I can’t help but judge Nolan for his rigidity, because the consequences are so stark,” Goldwyn says. “That’s an interesting kind of wrinkle in our relationship.”

“I feel like it’s surprisingly difficult to step outside of your own, from outside of your own perspective, and see anything a little bit differently. We all think that we’re really open-minded, but actually, we’re mostly blinking,” Dancy says, as Halevi agrees.
Dancy likes that “everybody gets nudged a little bit out of their comfort zone” in the debut episode and is “forced to look at the law from a slightly (different) angle.”
Halevi says she didn’t form an opinion about her character’s potential innocence or guilt.
“If she did it, I like her. If she didn’t do it, I like her,” she explains. “I think being guilty and being likable … could go together.”
“Could be compatible,” Dancy says.
“I think that’s what I really love about that episode,” Halevi says.
'Law & Order' Stars React to Ending of Season 25 Premiere

In the closing minutes, Price does step outside of his comfort zone and looks at the law differently. He overhears Maroun speaking to Mills’ girlfriend, Julia, a lawyer who stood by his side through his trial and becomes the police’s suspect in the shooting after Maroun is cleared. The girlfriend’s legal team argues Julia killed her boyfriend in advance as an act of self-defense because “he was going to kill her that night” and she “did what she had to do” by killing him first.

Julia later says Mills raped her, which leads Price to tell her and her lawyer they’d accept a guilty plea for man 1, which is also a move Baxter asked Price about: Was he doing this to “placate” Maroun after the Mills acquittal or because it’s “the right legal move”?
When Maroun and Julia are left in a moment alone, Maroun says she feels “terrible” about everything and Julia acknowledges she knows what Mills did to Maroun’s sister.

Julia gets emotional and apologizes, saying, “He thought that he could do whatever he wanted. He thought that he was above the law. That’s why I did what I did. That’s why I waited outside his damn condo, so that I could —” Maroun tells her to stop talking as Price overhears them from outside the room.

Maroun eventually tells Price what Julia said, aware that this would change everything about the case — just like Price choosing to turn over the evidence in the case against Mills led to an acquittal.

In a scene mirroring his earlier conversation with Baxter, Price asks Maroun what she thinks they should do. Maroun says they could share what she overheard, or they could both pretend not to have heard what Julia said and “accept the damn plea and move on.”
“Just because we can win the case based on a letter of the law, doesn’t mean we need to,” she adds.
Price ultimately agrees, thanking Maroun for “being so honest.”
Halevi says she believes her character “really taps into” Price’s heart, which is a sentiment Dancy agrees with, and “makes him explore the law” from a different angle.
She also sees Maroun as “the extreme of empathy” and Price as “the extreme of the letter of the law” and that the two “meet in the middle.”
The case brings the legal team of Baxter, Price and Maroun together in a way, but also introduces a new sort of dynamic into the group.

“I feel like that’s what happens in real life,” Halevi says. “You build really strong relationships with the people that challenged the relationship. Then you get disappointed, and you are forced to build trust.”
Goldwyn points out the events of the Mills case created “this strange tension” between Baxter and Price, that they “both kind of see the world quite differently.”

Dancy agrees, saying, “It’s a little less resolved between the two of us, because even going back to that story that he told me, which is supposedly a story about his own personal experience. So, it was kind of a human connection, turned out to be a fabrication.
“So from my perspective, it’s like, ‘Wait, so you just made something up so that I would cut corners in order to win the case.’”
Goldwyn interjects, “You don’t know that it was a fabrication.”
“I have good reason to believe it was a fabrication,” Dancy says, as they all laugh.

title: What Happened to Mehcad Brooks’ Character on ‘Law & Order’?
summary: Why did Mehcad Brooks' Detective Jalen Shaw leave "Law & Order"? The Season 25 premiere episode with Maura Tierney and Reid Scott reveals what happened.
story: The 27th Precinct is down one of its detectives as Season 25 of “Law & Order” gets underway.
Mehcad Brooks has officially left the franchise, and his character, Detective Jalen Shaw, is no longer working with Lt. Jessica Brady (Maura Tierney) and Detective Vincent Riley (Reid Scott).
Deadline first reported the news of Brooks’ departure in July. While the actor does not appear in the Sept. 25 premiere, the episode reveals the character’s fate.
What Happened to Detective Jalen Shaw on ‘Law & Order’
“I just spoke to Shaw,” Brady tells Riley, who was formerly partners with Shaw, in the Sept. 25 episode.
“Something opened up over at the 8-8, and he’s going to take it,” she says, referencing the New York City Police Department's 88th Precinct.
“I knew he wanted to get back to Brooklyn,” Riley responds. “So good for him.”
“I’m going to miss that guy, though,” he adds, smiling.
Shaw first appeared on “Law & Order: Organized Crime” as part of a crossover series of episodes with the mothership and “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” in 2022.

At the time, he worked for the 32nd Precinct and offered his assistance solving the case of a murdered girl, noting he was new to homicide and had spent the previous five years working in narcotics. He also had practiced law for three years after graduating from NYU before pivoting and enrolling in the police academy.
He joined the 27th Precinct after the case and was partnered up with Frank Cosgrove, played by Jeffrey Donovan. Donovan left the show after Season 22.
Scott replaced Donovan, and Riley and Shaw worked under Lt. Kate Dixon (Camryn Manheim) until her departure following Season 23. Tierney replaced her as the team’s lieutenant.
Why Did Mehcad Brooks Leave ‘Law & Order’?
It’s unclear why Brooks exited “Law & Order.”

His character replaced Detective Kevin Bernard, who was played by Anthony Anderson on both the original run of the series and its return in 2022 after 12 years off the air. Anderson left after that return season concluded.

During Brooks' time filming the crossover event, he had the chance to film scenes with “SVU” legend Mariska Hargitay. Before that, he guest-starred on an episode of the series in 2011. Brooks previously told TODAY.com in 2022 that he and Hargitay both “hit it off at that moment.”
“So, Mariska is the kind of person — I told her that my brother is the biggest ‘SVU’ fan in the world,” he said, adding that Hargitay then asked him for his brother’s number.
Brooks said Hargitay called his brother “out of the blue” a few months later to talk to him.
“My brother is going to remember that the rest of his life, and so that’s who she is,” he said. “She’s a legend in our house.”

title: Finneas O'Connell Engaged to Longtime Girlfriend Claudia Sulewski: See the Ring
summary: Finneas O'Connell, the musician and brother of Billie Eilish, proposed to his longtime girlfriend, Claudia Sulewski, after seven years of dating.
story: Finneas O'Connell proposed to his longtime girlfriend, Claudia Sulewski, after seven years of dating, and she said yes!
The couple announced their engagement in a joint Instagram post on Wednesday, Sept. 24.
"Forever and ever 9.22," the caption of the post read, seemingly referencing the date of the proposal.
The post included selfies of the musician and the influencer in the mountains, as well as a close-up shot of the ring on Sulewski's finger.

Simone Kendle, a ring expert and CEO of Wove, tells TODAY.com Sulewski's ring appears to be a 6-to-7-carat elongated cushion-cut diamond, which leans into the vintage revival aesthetic trending in jewelry today.

"It whispers elegance and restraint," Kendle says. "The design suggests that the wearer values timeless refinement rather than flamboyance. There’s a quiet confidence in saying, 'I don’t need extra frills; the center stone is enough.'"
Laura Taylor, a jeweler specializing in engagement and wedding rings at Lorel Diamonds, estimates the ring at 4 to 5 carats, set on a platinum band.

“Cushion cuts are a timeless choice, known for their rounded corners and larger facets that make the stone flash in the light rather than sparkle," Taylor tells TODAY.com. "They’re often chosen by people who want something romantic and elegant but still with plenty of presence on the hand to capture attention."
Without knowing the exact specifications of the ring, Kendle estimates the value to be between $200,000 to $300,000, while Taylor gives an estimate of $330,000 to $400,000.

“However, Finneas comes from a family who holds strong values around sustainability and ethics, which means it’s very possible he chose a lab-grown diamond, which would bring the value closer to ($40,000 to $55,000),” Taylor says.
Sulewski, 29, said she met O'Connell, the brother of Billie Eilish who performs under the name Finneas, on Raya in September 2018.
Sulewski discussed matching with Finneas on the celebrity dating app on “The Skinny Confidential Him & Her Podcast” in 2020.
“Everything fell into place so perfectly and so quickly,” she said, “because we already knew so many people in the same friend group.”
In 2019, the pair bought a home together, and Finneas has dedicated songs to Sulewski, including his 2019 track, "Claudia."
Sulewski, who rose to fame with her beauty YouTube channel in the early 2010s and later founded body care brand Cyklar, told TODAY.com about her relationship with Finneas in 2023.
“Finneas is just so wonderful and one of, like, the most creative brains — so I feel lucky just to get to pick his brain whenever, and he does the same with me,” she said.
“I feel really lucky to have a supportive partner that I really respect and that goes mutually both ways,” she added. “And so I couldn’t ask for a better best friend to get to bounce ideas off of.”
Sulewski has also directed music videos for Finneas, including the visual for his track "2001," which dropped in May 2025 and starred Kate Hudson alongside the singer.

title: Has Jenna & Friends Brought Someone New Into Your Life?

story: Has Jenna & Friends brought someone new into your life?
Whether at a remote show, on the plaza, through a fan group or more, we want to hear all about it!
In the form below, share how your love of the show brought someone new and meaningful into your life. Please share a photo of you and your friend too!
A TODAY producer will be in touch if your submission is selected.

title: William Shatner Responds to Reports He's in the Hospital
summary: William Shatner has responded to a report saying he was hospitalized with a Mark Twain-themed response that he "overindulged" and is "perfectly fine."
story: William Shatner has responded to a report saying he was hospitalized with a Mark Twain-themed response that he "overindulged" and is "perfectly fine."

The 94-year-old "Star Trek" icon shared a meme of himself on X on Sept. 25 that showed him as author Mark Twain with the quote "Rumors of my demise have been greatly exaggerated!" The line is a famously misremembered quote from Twain in which he refuted rumors about his death.
"I over indulged," Shatner wrote. "I thank you all for caring but I’m perfectly fine. I keep telling you all: don’t trust tabloids or AI!"
A report by TMZ said that the actor who portrayed the iconic Captain Kirk had been rushed to the hospital on Sept. 24 after suffering a medical emergency.
Shatner has been living long and prospering into his 90s, almost 60 years after he first played Capt. Kirk in the legendary science fiction series.
He spoke with NBC News in 2018 about his secret to longevity.

“My life has been so lucky — I’ve been so fortunate in terms of health, which is really the basis of everything,” he said. “Your health and your energy is partially your doing, but partially accidental — genetic and accidental.”
